Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Investigating the impact of climatic stress on root chemistry using spectroscopic techniques

Plant roots contribute a majority of the carbon sequestered in terrestrial ecosystems. The stability of this sequestered carbon is governed by the overall molecular identity of the litter matrix. Projected increases in temperature and frequent droughts by the turn of this century may impose severe moisture stress in plants, altering the plant metabolic pathways resulting in unique metabolite profiles and biopolymer chemistry of the roots. This unprecedented change in the structural chemistry and composition (quality) of root biopolymers would further alter their microbial symbiotic associations. The change in root biopolymer chemistry and microbial associations would, in turn, alter the stability and turnover of root carbon in soil. Advanced spectroscopic techniques and chemometric analyses are promising tools to capture the climatic stress induced qualitative changes in root chemistry and further help to predict root litter decomposition under future climates.

Training objectives include attaining proficiency in advanced spectroscopic and mass spectrometric analyses and computational techniques. The project integrates physical science techniques with biology to develop an interdisciplinary research program. The fellow will actively recruit and mentor high school and undergraduate students through the proposed research. Additionally, the fellow will give guest lectures and present research in national and international conferences and disseminate findings of the research through publications in peer-reviewed journals and to the non-scientific community through popular science magazines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Projected increase in temperature and frequent droughts pose stressful climatic conditions for plant growth potentially affecting food, fodder and fuel production. A comprehensive understanding of the responses of plants to stressful climatic conditions is critical to develop management practices that would enhance plant productivity and soil carbon storage. A majority of carbon in soils is directly or indirectly derived from plant roots. Thus, the chemistry of root tissues is an important parameter that regulate their potential to contribute to soil carbon. Adverse climatic conditions would alter root tissue chemical composition and root-fungal associations that would modify their potential to contribute to soil carbon. Root tissues contain many polymeric compounds such as suberin, lignin and tannins that help them to defend against pests and pathogens while concurrently allowing them to maximize their resource uptake functions. Using advanced spectroscopic and spectrometric techniques, I examined the changes in the structural and metabolic components of root tissues subjected to warming, drought and elevated carbon oxide conditions. Roots that were subjected to elevated CO2 and warming not only had higher content of suberin but these treatments also altered the chemical composition of suberin. Plant tissues subjected to drought and warming treatments had greater amount of metabolites such as amino acids, organic acids and phenolic acids that help plants to mitigate climatic stress. The greater amount of tannins produced in these tissues under drought and warmer climates also decreased the amount of nitrogen that was re-absorbed back to trees. Plant tissues subjected to drought and warmer conditions with greater amount of recalcitrant compounds had lower rate of decomposition as they were energetically less favorable to microbial decomposers. This would slow nutrient cycling in ecosystems affecting plant productivity and soil carbon storage under future climates.

This research has many implications beyond environmental sciences. The finer level characterization of biopolymers would contribute to our understanding of the enzymatic degradation of plant biomass for bioenergy production, and facilitate the development of sustainable bioenergy crops. The results would also potentially inform land management practices in degraded ecosystems (both agricultural and forested landscapes) through plant root mediated soil carbon storage. The research involved collaboration with multiple institutions and trained five high school students, five undergraduates, two graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow. Among these students more than 50% belonged to women researchers and also included students from minority groups. The results were disseminated through publications, and presentations at national and regional conferences and informal meetings with the general public.
